question: Does the outer mitochondrial membrane lipid composition modulate VDAC-ligand interactions differently in healthy vs cancer mitochondria? Specifically: (1) Cardiolipin is enriched in inner mitochondrial membrane but present in OMM contact sites — does it alter VDAC gating or CBD binding at these sites? (2) Cancer cell membranes have altered cholesterol/phospholipid ratios — does this change the effective Kd of lipophilic VDAC modulators like CBD (logP 6.3)? (3) Olesoxime (TRO19622) binds VDAC via a cholesterol-recognition motif — does membrane cholesterol content determine whether olesoxime is neuroprotective or neutral? (4) Could membrane-targeted delivery (liposomes with specific lipid compositions) enhance or reduce VDAC modulator potency in a cell-type-specific way?

gate.recommendation: Lab Gate PASSED. 17/17 claims cleared all three criteria. Proceeding to S4 hypothesis operationalization.

hypotheses.prediction: IF VDAC1 is reconstituted in planar lipid bilayers containing 10-20 mol% cardiolipin (vs pure POPC), THEN voltage-gating midpoint shifts by 10-20 mV toward more negative potentials AND CBD Kd decreases by ≥2-fold (from ~11 µM to ≤5.5 µM).

IF VDAC1 is embedded in nanodiscs with 20 mol% cholesterol (cancer-mimetic) vs 5 mol% (healthy-mimetic), THEN the apparent CBD-VDAC1 Kd decreases from ~11 µM to 3-6 µM due to enhanced local partitioning, placing it within the 1-10 µM therapeutic window.

IF OMM cholesterol is depleted below ~15 mol% (via MβCD treatment or low-cholesterol nanodiscs), THEN olesoxime-VDAC1 binding affinity drops by ≥5-fold AND neuroprotective activity (prevention of cytochrome c release) is abolished.

IF CBD is delivered via liposomes matching cancer OMM composition (20 mol% cholesterol, 5 mol% CL, 75% POPC) vs generic liposomes (100% POPC), THEN IC₅₀ for cancer cell killing decreases by ≥3-fold in cancer lines (HCT116, MDA-MB-231) while remaining unchanged or increasing in normal cells (MCF10A, primary hepatocytes), with the differential being VDAC1-dependent.

protocols.prediction: IF VDAC1 is reconstituted in planar lipid bilayers containing 10-20 mol% cardiolipin (vs pure POPC), THEN voltage-gating midpoint shifts by 10-20 mV toward more negative potentials AND CBD Kd decreases by ≥2-fold (from ~11 µM to ≤5.5 µM).
protocols.protocol: Reconstitute purified human VDAC1 into planar lipid bilayers (POPC alone vs POPC:CL 85:15). Measure single-channel conductance and voltage-gating curves (±60 mV triangular ramps, n≥30 insertions per condition). Determine CBD Kd via
controls: CL-containing bilayers without VDAC (membrane-only CBD partitioning)
protocols.expected_outcome: CL-containing bilayers show V₀ shift of −12 to −18 mV; CBD IC₅₀ for conductance inhibition drops from ~11 µM to ~4-6 µM; MST confirms Kd shift.
protocols.null_outcome: No significant V₀ shift (<5 mV) and CBD Kd remains 9-13 µM regardless of CL content.

protocols.prediction: IF VDAC1 is embedded in nanodiscs with 20 mol% cholesterol (cancer-mimetic) vs 5 mol% (healthy-mimetic), THEN the apparent CBD-VDAC1 Kd decreases from ~11 µM to 3-6 µM due to enhanced local partitioning, placing it within the 1-10 µM therapeutic window.
protocols.protocol: Assemble MSP1D1-based nanodiscs with POPC + 5 mol% or 20 mol% cholesterol, each containing single VDAC1. Measure CBD binding by MST (label VDAC1 with RED-NHS) and independently by ITC. Quantify free vs membrane-partitioned CBD using equilibrium dialysis with ³H-CBD or LC-MS/MS. Parallel SPR with VDAC1-nanodiscs immobilized on L1 chip. Timeline: 6-8 weeks.
controls: Empty nanodiscs (no VDAC1) for partitioning-only measurement
VDAC1 in detergent micelles (lipid-free Kd reference)
protocols.expected_outcome: Apparent Kd drops 2-3 fold in 20% cholesterol nanodiscs; equilibrium dialysis confirms 2-3× higher CBD retention in cholesterol-rich nanodiscs; SPR kon increases while koff is unchanged.
protocols.null_outcome: Kd values within 20% of each other across cholesterol conditions; or Kd increases* in high-cholesterol nanodiscs (supporting claims [5]/[9] that cholesterol sequesters CBD away from VDAC).

protocols.prediction: IF OMM cholesterol is depleted below ~15 mol% (via MβCD treatment or low-cholesterol nanodiscs), THEN olesoxime-VDAC1 binding affinity drops by ≥5-fold AND neuroprotective activity (prevention of cytochrome c release) is abolished.
protocols.protocol: (A) Biophysical: Measure olesoxime binding to VDAC1 in nanodiscs with 5, 10, 15, 20, 25, 30 mol% cholesterol by MST and ITC, generating a full cholesterol-dependence curve. (B) Cellular: Treat SH-SY5Y neurons with 5 mM MβCD (titrated to achieve 40-70% cholesterol depletion, verified by Amplex Red), then challenge with staurosporine (1 µM) ± olesoxime (1-30 µM). Measure cytochrome c release (ELISA from cytosolic fraction), ΔΨm (TMRE), and viability (CellTiter-Glo). Include cholesterol repletion rescue arm. Timeline: 10-12 weeks.
protocols.expected_outcome: Sigmoidal cholesterol-dependence curve for olesoxime binding with inflection at ~15-20 mol%; MβCD-treated neurons show complete loss of olesoxime neuroprotection; cholesterol repletion restores protection.
protocols.null_outcome: Olesoxime binds VDAC1 with similar affinity (within 2-fold) regardless of cholesterol content; MβCD-treated neurons still protected by olesoxime.

protocols.prediction: IF CBD is delivered via liposomes matching cancer OMM composition (20 mol% cholesterol, 5 mol% CL, 75% POPC) vs generic liposomes (100% POPC), THEN IC₅₀ for cancer cell killing decreases by ≥3-fold in cancer lines (HCT116, MDA-MB-231) while remaining unchanged or increasing in normal cells (MCF10A, primary hepatocytes), with the differential being VDAC1-dependent.
protocols.protocol: Prepare liposomes by thin-film hydration + extrusion (100 nm): (i) cancer-mimetic (POPC:Chol:CL 75:20:5), (ii) healthy-mimetic (POPC:Chol:CL 90:5:5), (iii) generic (POPC only), all loaded with CBD. Characterize by DLS, zeta potential, HPLC (encapsulation). Treat HCT116, M

final_claims.statement: Cardiolipin at OMM-IMM contact sites stabilizes VDAC in a partially closed state, altering both gating voltage-dependence and the accessibility of CBD's binding site.
final_claims.mechanism: Cardiolipin's negative charge and cone-shape geometry modify VDAC barrel lipid-facing residues and electrostatic surface potential, shifting voltage-gating thresholds by ~10-20 mV as shown in reconstituted systems.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Electrophysiology of VDAC in cardiolipin-free vs cardiolipin-containing planar bilayers showing no gating shift and unchanged CBD Kd.

final_claims.statement: Cancer cell OMM cholesterol enrichment (typically 2-4× vs normal) increases membrane partitioning of CBD, raising local membrane concentration and reducing the apparent Kd from ~11 µM (bulk) to an effective ~3-6 µM at the VDAC interface.
final_claims.mechanism: Cholesterol-rich membranes increase the partition coefficient of high-logP compounds; for CBD (logP 6.3), a 2-3× cholesterol increase could raise local [CBD] ~2-3 fold via enhanced hydrophobic retention, but cholesterol also rigidifies the membrane, potentially occluding binding grooves.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: SPR or MST measurement of CBD-VDAC Kd in nanodiscs with defined cholesterol content (5% vs 20% mol) showing no Kd shift.

final_claims.statement: Olesoxime efficacy is membrane-cholesterol-dependent because its CRAC motif mediates initial membrane anchoring; in low-cholesterol membranes (neurons under stress), olesoxime partitions less efficiently, explaining variable neuroprotective outcomes across trials.
final_claims.mechanism: CRAC-motif-cholesterol interaction serves as a prerequisite membrane docking step before lateral diffusion to VDAC; cholesterol depletion (e.g., MβCD) should abolish olesoxime-VDAC interaction.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Olesoxime binding to VDAC measured ± MβCD treatment showing cholesterol-independent binding.

final_claims.statement: Liposomes engineered with cancer-mimetic lipid compositions (high cholesterol, low cardiolipin) would enhance CBD delivery to cancer OMM, potentially achieving VDAC-selective concentrations within the 1-10 µM therapeutic window while remaining below TRPV1/PPARγ activation thresholds.
final_claims.mechanism: Fusogenic liposomes matching target OMM composition preferentially transfer lipophilic cargo via membrane fusion; composition matching reduces thermodynamic barrier to transfer.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: In vitro cytotoxicity assay showing no differential potency of CBD-loaded cancer-mimetic vs generic liposomes on cancer vs normal cells. ───

final_claims.statement: Cardiolipin at OMM contact sites increases VDAC’s open probability and reduces CBD binding affinity by ~2-fold.
final_claims.mechanism: CL’s negative curvature stabilizes VDAC’s open state via electrostatic interactions with basic residues, competing with CBD’s hydrophobic binding pocket.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Reconstitution assays showing CBD Kd >20 µM in CL-enriched liposomes vs. 11 µM in control (Rimmerman baseline).

final_claims.statement: Cancer mitochondria’s elevated cholesterol/phospholipid ratio increases CBD’s effective Kd by 3–5 µM due to reduced membrane partitioning.
final_claims.mechanism: Cholesterol rigidifies membranes, lowering CBD’s free concentration at VDAC by ~30% (logP-dependent sequestration).
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Kd measurements in cancer vs. healthy OMM vesicles showing CBD Kd >14 µM in high-cholesterol conditions.

final_claims.statement: Olesoxime’s neuroprotection requires >20 mol% cholesterol in OMM; below this threshold, it becomes neutral or cytotoxic.
final_claims.mechanism: Cholesterol’s CRAC motif binding may allosterically stabilize VDAC’s closed state, preventing cytochrome c release.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Olesoxime dose-response curves in neurons with cholesterol-depleted OMM (e.g., MβCD-treated) showing loss of protection at <15 mol% cholesterol.

final_claims.statement: Liposomes with 1:1 CL/cholesterol enhance CBD potency in cancer cells (Kd ~5 µM) but reduce it in healthy cells (Kd ~20 µM).
final_claims.mechanism: CL-rich liposomes fuse preferentially with cancer OMM (high curvature), increasing local CBD concentration, while cholesterol-rich liposomes stabilize healthy OMM.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Cell-type-specific Kd measurements with lipid-tailored liposomes showing opposite potency shifts. --- ### ───

final_claims.statement: Cardiolipin at OMM contact sites stabilizes VDAC in open conformation, potentially enhancing CBD binding.
final_claims.mechanism: CL directly binds VDAC C-terminal helix, promoting monomeric/open states that expose ligand sites.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: No Kd shift for CBD in CL-enriched vs PC liposomes via SPR.

final_claims.statement: Cancer OMM higher chol/PL ratio increases membrane order, reducing effective CBD concentration at VDAC due to sequestration.
final_claims.mechanism: Lipophilic CBD (logP 6.3, Kd=11μM) partitions preferentially into ordered chol-rich domains, lowering free [CBD] for VDAC.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Identical CBD-VDAC Kd in cancer-mimic vs healthy-mimic liposomes by ITC.

final_claims.statement: Olesoxime VDAC binding/efficacy depends on OMM cholesterol, enabling neuroprotection in chol-high healthy mitochondria.
final_claims.mechanism: CRAC motif requires chol for membrane insertion/VDAC stabilization; low chol (e.g., cancer) abolishes affinity.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: No potency difference in chol-depleted vs native mito liposomes for neuroprotection assays.

final_claims.statement: Lipid-specific liposomes can enhance VDAC modulator potency >2x in cancer cells via chol-targeted delivery.
final_claims.mechanism: Cancer OMM-like chol/PL liposomes increase local modulator partitioning, shifting effective Kd into therapeutic window (1-10μM).
final_claims.falsifiable_by: No potency gain in vivo for chol-mimic liposomes vs plain in cancer xenografts. ───

final_claims.statement: The higher cholesterol content in cancer cell OMM increases the local concentration of highly lipophilic drugs like CBD (logP 6.3), lowering the effective VDAC1-CBD Kd below the reported 11.0 uM and making VDAC a more prominent target within the therapeutic window [1.0, 10.0] uM specifically in cancer cells.
final_claims.mechanism: Increased membrane cholesterol enhances the partitioning of hydrophobic molecules into the OMM, elevating the drug concentration in the direct vicinity of VDAC and thus increasing the apparent binding affinity.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Measuring CBD-VDAC1 binding in proteoliposomes with low (healthy) vs. high (cancer-like) cholesterol content and finding no significant change in the measured Kd.

final_claims.statement: Olesoxime's therapeutic activity is strictly dependent on a narrow range of membrane cholesterol concentration, making it neuroprotective in healthy neurons but inert in cells with dysregulated cholesterol metabolism (e.g., certain cancers or neurodegenerative states).
final_claims.mechanism: Olesoxime's cholesterol-recognition amino acid consensus (CRAC) motif requires a direct interaction with a cholesterol molecule to achieve the correct conformation for high-affinity binding to VDAC, and this ternary complex is unstable outside an optimal cholesterol concentration range.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Demonstrating that olesoxime retains VDAC binding and cytoprotective activity in cells that have been artificially depleted of or overloaded with membrane cholesterol.

final_claims.statement: Liposomes formulated with a cancer-like lipid profile (e.g., high cholesterol, low cardiolipin) will deliver VDAC modulators to cancer mitochondria more effectively than liposomes with a healthy lipid profile, increasing drug potency.
final_claims.mechanism: Enhanced membrane fusion and/or lipid exchange between vesicles and the OMM is favored when their lipid compositions are similar, leading to more efficient drug transfer.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Showing that the IC50 of a VDAC-targeting drug delivered by cancer-mimicking vs. healthy-mimicking liposomes is identical in a cancer cell line. ───

final_claims.statement: Cardiolipin at OMM contact sites alters VDAC gating dynamics, likely promoting a conformation with higher affinity for certain ligands (e.g., olesoxime) but not necessarily CBD.
final_claims.mechanism: Cardiolipin's negative charge and conical shape distort local membrane curvature and electrostatics, stabilizing specific VDAC oligomeric states or tilts.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: In vitro electrophysiology showing identical VDAC gating in pure PC vs PC+cardiolipin membranes.

final_claims.statement: Increased OMM cholesterol in some cancers significantly raises the effective local concentration of CBD at VDAC, lowering its apparent functional Kd below the measured 11 µM.
final_claims.mechanism: Higher cholesterol increases membrane order and partition coefficient for lipophilic CBD (logP 6.3), enriching it in the OMM and increasing probability of VDAC interaction.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Measuring CBD binding to VDAC in lipid nanodiscs with high vs low cholesterol showing no Kd difference.

final_claims.statement: Olesoxime's neuroprotective effect requires an optimal, intermediate OMM cholesterol level, explaining its cell-type-specific activity.
final_claims.mechanism: Too little cholesterol prevents olesoxime's membrane recruitment via its cholesterol-recognition motif; too much cholesterol competitively inhibits its specific binding site on VDAC.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Olesoxime showing identical VDAC binding and cytoprotection in cells with very high and very low membrane cholesterol. ───
